awd_abstract_narration:
Professor William Noid of the Pennsylvania State University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry division to develop low-resolution (coarse-grained (CG)) models of soft materials at interfaces.  Soft materials include colloids, gels, polymers, liquid crystals, foams and biological tissues.  An example of an interface is when liquid comes into contact with air. Interfacial phenomena are fundamentally interesting.  They also have tremendous practical significance, since they control the performance of many modern materials and devices.  Because computer simulation allow us to visualize the structure, organization, interactions and changes of interfaces, they hold great promise for helping us understand interfacial phenomena.  Computer simulations are useful for designing interfaces with desired material properties.  However, simulations that include all the atomic details of the interface are very computationally expensive.  This expense severely limits their use for understanding interfacial systems.  Coarse-grained (CG) models are less expensive computational methods.  By representing molecules in reduced detail, CG models provide the necessary computational efficiency for effectively simulating length- and time-scales that cannot be effectively addressed with atomistic models.  In this research, Professor Noid and his coworkers develop CG models that accurately describe interfacial phenomena.  Additionally, this project develops an intergenerational science club that integrates Penn State students, emeritus faculty, and local retirees in discovery-based scientific education and discourse.  


"Bottom-up" CG models are not only exceedingly efficient, but also provide an accurate description of the structural properties of homogeneous materials.  Unfortunately, these models generally provide a poor description of interfaces and other inhomogeneous systems.   Accordingly, the central goal of this research is to develop theory and computational methods for parameterizing and simulating CG models that accurately model the structure and thermodynamic properties of inhomogeneous systems.  The resulting insight and software may enable highly efficient simulations that provide a realistic description of interfacial systems and, ultimately, guide the design of specific material systems with desired interfacial properties. In order to achieve these goals, the research develops rigorous theory and numerical calculations to understand why current bottom-up models provide a poor description of inhomogeneous systems.  The research also develops robust computational methods for addressing these limitations in practice.  In particular, a generalized-Yvon-Born-Green formalism quantifies the force imbalances that arise at the CG interfaces and illuminates useful connections with classical density functional theories for inhomogeneous systems.  A grand canonical formalism provides insights into the thermodynamic consistency of CG models and also determines effective potentials that are transferable to both homogeneous and inhomogeneous environments.  The resulting advances provide tools for investigating soft material interfaces and, in particular, the structure and thermodynamic properties of solid-liquid and polymer-substrate interfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Interfaces play a critical role in the development of modern devices and future technologies. By directly modeling the structure, dynamics, and interactions of molecules at interfaces, computer simulations provide an essential tool for characterizing and understanding these complex, inhomogeneous environments. However, the computational effort required to simulate atomically detailed models severely limits their scope. Consequently, many computational studies adopt lower-resolution coarse-grained (CG) models to study interfacial environments. By averaging over atomic details, CG models provide the necessary computational effort for simulating length- and time-scales that cannot be effectively addressed with atomically detailed models. Unfortunately, as a consequence of averaging over atomic interactions, the interactions in CG models depend upon thermodynamic conditions, such as temperature, and also often vary between bulk and interfacial environments. Consequently, CG models often demonstrate limited transferability, i.e., models that accurately describe one set of conditions may provide a poor description under different conditions. This lack of transferability threatens to undermine the utility of CG models. Moreover, this averaging over atomic interactions complicates the description of thermodynamic properties. Despite the tremendous promise of CG models, the theory and computational methods necessary for developing predictive CG models are still being developed.

This project addressed these challenges by advancing both theory and computational methods for predictive CG models of interfaces. In particular, we developed a fundamental framework for developing CG models of inhomogeneous systems. This framework provides a rigorous methodology for deriving potentials that describe both intermolecular interactions and also interactions with an external field. This framework explicitly clarifies the contribution of external environments to the interactions in CG models. Moreover, this framework clarifies the relationship between modern computational models and much older analytic theories for liquid interfaces. 

We also developed advanced computational tools for modeling interfaces. Specifically, we provided considerable insight into local density (LD) potentials that describe interactions as a function of the number of molecules in the surrounding environment. We derived a surprising relationship between these LD potentials and more traditional pair potentials that describe intermolecular interactions as a function of the distance between molecules. We demonstrated that LD potentials provide outstanding accuracy and transferability for modeling both homogeneous bulk liquid environments and inhomogeneous interfaces. In particular, they very accurately model both the intermolecular packing in homogeneous liquids, as well as the intermolecular structure of solid-liquid and liquid-vapor interfaces. Moreover, we demonstrated that LD potentials describe thermodynamic properties, such as the internal pressure, with remarkable accuracy. Furthermore, we generalized these potentials to account for gradients in the local density. 

Additionally, we developed a rigorous theory and associated computational methodology for modeling thermodynamic properties, such as energy and entropy, as well as for determining the details that should be preserved in CG models. In particular, we developed a dual approach that improves the transferability of CG models by predicting how their interactions vary with temperature. This dual approach rigorously describes important thermodynamic properties, such as the specific heat, that were previously considered inaccessible to low-resolution coarse-grained models. 

Finally, this project contributed several different broader impacts to society. The project provided mentorship and training for four graduate students and one undergraduate student. By developing new software and methods, this project contributed to the national computational infrastructure for modeling soft materials and their interfaces.  Additionally, the project developed an outreach program that bridges the academic and local retirement communities to engage local senior citizens in scientific discussion and education.
